articles.name: How to Activate Your Account, Access Your Account, and Reset Your Password
articles.title: How to Activate Your Account, Access Your Account, and Reset Your Password
articles.body:
Activating and Accessing Your Account

If you have never logged in to the KCM GRC platform, once your administrator has created an account for you, you will receive an email asking you to confirm your account.

If you did not receive this email, be sure to check your Junk or Spam folder. If you don't see the email there, reach out to your KCM GRC administrator and request that they resend the activation email. 

Follow the instructions in the email to activate your account. Then, create and confirm your password.

  • If you are not prompted to create a password, your administrator may have set up Single Sign-On/SAML for your KCM GRC platform. See Activating and Accessing Your Account With SSO/SAML for details.
Tip: Once you've reached the login page, bookmark this page or save the URL to easily access your account in the future.

How Do I Reset My Password?

From the login page of your organization's account, click the Forgot Password? link. Then, enter your email address and click the Send Email button. 

You will receive an email that contains a link and a code that you will use to reset your password. Follow the instructions in the email. Then, create and confirm your new password.

Note: If Single Sign-On/SAML is configured for your account, you will not receive a password reset email (unless you are an Account Administrator, Vendor, or Auditor user). Please see Activating and Accessing Your Account With SSO/SAML for more information. If you need additional assistance with accessing your account, contact your account administrator.

articles.name: FAQ: Second Chance
articles.title: FAQ: Second Chance
articles.body:
Below are some commonly-asked questions about KnowBe4's Second Chance. If you don't see the answer you need, submit a ticket to our support team.

What file types work with Second Chance?

Second Chance will prompt the user when they click a link from any Office file (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) or PDF attachment. PDF attachments must be opened in Adobe Reader DC, Sumatra, or Foxit Reader.

What URL rewrites and shorteners are Second Chance compatible with?

The following table includes all of Second Chance's compatible URL rewrites and shorteners:

Supported URL Shorteners
Name URL
Bitly bit.ly
Bitdo bit.do
Capsulink cli.re, [www.]capsulink.com
Googl goo.gl
Owly ow.ly
TinyURL tinyurl.com
Supported URL Rewriters
Name URL
Barracuda linkprotect.cudasvc.com
Cisco secure-web.cisco.com
FireEye *.fireeye.com
Google (Gmail) [www.]google.com
Mimecast protect-*.mimecast.com
Outlook *.safelinks.protection.outlook.com
PostOffice clicktime.cloud.postoffice.net
Proofpoint urldefense.proofpoint.com
Sophos *.protection.sophos.com
Symantec clicktime.symantec.com
TrendMicro  *.trendmicro.com
Trustwave  scanmail.trustwave.com

Does Second Chance work with Outlook Web Access?

No. Outlook Web Access is not supported.

Can I have a list of KnowBe4's No Prompt Domains?

For security reasons, we can not share a list of our No Prompt Domains. Additionally, since the list is constantly changing, the data on the list would become outdated quickly.

My users are clicking continue, but their browser window isn't appearing.

The browser window will not appear as a pop up on the screen after clicking, so it has most likely been opened. Depending on the default browser, there may be a flashing browser icon in the taskbar indicating a new link has been opened. Instruct your user to double-check their browser after clicking the Second Chance prompt to continue to the website, as it should have been opened.

After installing Second Chance, I'm getting an error when I open Excel.

The error message The program can't start because MSVCR90.dll is missing from your computer. Try reinstalling the program to fix this problem is due to a known compatibility issue with Windows 10, Excel 2010, and Sophos/Hitman Pro.

How is my data encrypted?

Your data is encrypted via HTTPS. This data falls under our normal privacy standards. For more details, see our privacy policy on our Product Privacy page.

I'm not receiving Second Chance prompts after installing through Group Policy.

If you’ve installed through Group Policy and you are not seeing Second Chance prompts, follow the below steps on the client machine where it should be been installed:

  1. Check your Add/Remove Programs list for "Second Chance". If you don't see it, attempt to follow the Command Prompt instructions shown below. If you do see Second Chance in your list of Programs, move on to the next step.
  2. Open the Services application, services. msc, and check to see if the following services are running. If not, you can restart the computer or start or restart the services so that you can receive Second Chance prompts when you click a link. 
    • knowbe4.secondchance.service
    • knowbe4.secondchance.opmanger
  3. Command Prompt Instructions:
    • Open an elevated Command Prompt (cmd) (run as Admin) on the client device you’re attempting the install on and enter the following commands to troubleshoot:
      • gpupdate /forceThis entry will force an update of Group Policy on the client machine you are logged in to.
      • gpresult /rThis entry will let you review whether or not the Group Policy you set up is being applied to the client machine you are logged in to.
  4. Make sure you are using a UNC file path with your GPO installation (Example: \\Server\Volume\File).
  5. Restart the machine you're trying to install Second Chance on.
  6. If installing using a .bat file, it needs to be run with sufficient privileges.

articles.name: How to Create Custom Templates for Scopes
articles.title: How to Create Custom Templates for Scopes
articles.body:
In KCM GRC, a template holds a set of requirements that you can work toward under a scope. To help you meet your compliance objectives, we offer a variety of managed templates that you can use in your platform. We are continually adding new templates to KCM GRC based on the number of requests that we receive. For a current list of all managed templates that we offer, please see our Managed Templates article. 

If your organization needs to work toward a scope that we do not offer as a managed template, you can create a custom template for your platform. You can add requirements to the custom template by importing requirements in bulk, mapping existing requirements, or creating requirements one-by-one. Then, you can convert the custom template into a scope and begin working toward its scoped requirements. 

Please see the sections below to learn how to create a custom template, prepare a set of requirements, and add requirements to the custom template.

Tip: If you have already created a template and added requirements to it, refer to our How to Convert a Template to a Scope article to learn how to convert the template to a scope.

Creating a Custom Template

First, create a custom template by following the instructions below. 

  1. From the navigation panel, select Compliance > Templates.
  2. Click the Create button in the top-right area of the page.
  3. In the Create Template window, add details to your template by following the instructions below. 
    Note:We recommend that you avoid including the < and > special characters in these fields. 
    1. Name: Enter a name for the custom template. The name should either represent the type of requirements that you will add to the template or the objective of meeting the requirements in the template.
    2. Version: Enter the template's version or revision number. This information is for your own reference.
    3. Tag(s): (Optional) If you'd like, add one or more tags to group similar templates in your platform.
      • To create a new tag, type one or more words into the field, and press Enter on your keyboard. Tags have a maximum of 25 characters, including spaces.
      • To select an existing tag, select a tag from the drop-down menu.
  4. Click Create to save your new template.

Once you've created a template, the next step is to add requirements. See the sections below to learn about requirements and the methods that you can use to add requirements to a template.

Identifying Actionable Requirements

As a best practice, the requirements that you add to your template should all be actionable. Actionable requirements include an action that your organization must perform to meet an objective. Often, actionable requirements clearly state what you need to do to comply with a regulation or standard. Requirements that are not actionable do not prompt your organization to perform a specific action. Many requirements that are not actionable only involve other parts of the document, such as other requirements or chapters. By only adding actionable requirements, your organization will be able to focus on the objectives that you are working to meet. 

Please see the table below for examples of requirements that are actionable and requirements that are not actionable.

Note:These examples are from our HIPAA Privacy and Breach v1.0 managed template.
Actionable Not Actionable

164.508 (c)(4) Authorization - Copy to the Individual

If a covered entity seeks an authorization from an individual for a use or disclosure of protected health information, the covered entity must provide the individual with a copy of the signed authorization.

Explanation: This requirement clearly tells you what you need to do to comply with the regulation. The action is to give a copy of the signed authorization to the person who authorized the disclosure.

164.414 (a) Administrative Requirements and Burden of Proof

A covered entity is required to comply with theadministrative requirements of 164.530(b), (d), (e), (g), (h), (i), and (j) with respect to the requirements of this subpart.

Explanation: The only action in this requirement applies to other requirements in the document. This requirement does not clearly tell you what to do to comply with a regulation.

164.404 (a)(1) Breach Notification to Individuals - Notification

A covered entity shall, following the discovery of a breach of unsecured protected health information, notify each individual whose unsecured protected health information has been, or is reasonably believed by the covered entity to have been, accessed, acquired, used, or disclosed as a result of such breach.

Explanation: This requirement clearly tells you what you need to do to comply with the regulation. The action is to notify individuals that their information was involved in a data breach. 

164.502 (g)(1) Personal Representatives

As specified in this paragraph, a covered entity must, except as provided in paragraphs (g)(3) and (g)(5) of this section, treat a personal representative as the individual for purposes of this subchapter.

Explanation: The only action in this requirement applies to the subchapter of the document. This requirement does not clearly tell you what to do to comply with a regulation. 

164.502 (a)(4) Business Associates: Required Uses and Disclosures

A business associate is required to disclose protected health information:(i) When required by the Secretary under subpart C of part 160 of this subchapter to investigate or determine the business associate's compliance with this subchapter.(ii) To the covered entity, individual, or individual's designee, as necessary to satisfy a covered entity's obligations under 164.524(c)(2)(ii) and (3)(ii) with respect to an individual's request for an electronic copy of protected health information.

Explanation: This requirement clearly tells you what you need to do to comply with the regulation. The action is to disclose protected health information in the two situations that are listed in (i) and (ii). 

164.502 (b)(2) Minimum Necessary Does Not Apply

This requirement does not apply to:(i) Disclosures to or requests by a health care provider for treatment; (ii) Uses or disclosures made to the individual, as permitted under paragraph (a)(1)(i) of this section or as required by paragraph (a)(2)(i) of this section;(iii) Uses or disclosures made pursuant to an authorization under 164.508; (iv) Disclosures made to the Secretary in accordance with subpart C of part 160 of this subchapter; (v) Uses or disclosures that are required by law, asdescribed by 164.512(a); and (vi) Uses or disclosures that are required for compliance with applicable requirements of this subchapter.Explanation: The requirement only applies to the document and does not include an action. This requirement does not clearly tell you what to do to comply with a regulation.

Importing Requirements in Bulk

Importing your requirements in bulk is the most efficient way to add requirements to a template. We recommend that you import your requirements in bulk if your requirements directly come from an existing regulation or framework.

See the subsections below to learn how to prepare a spreadsheet of requirements and import the spreadsheet into your platform.

Preparing a Spreadsheet of Requirements

After you create your custom template, you can prepare a spreadsheet of requirements.

To prepare your spreadsheet, follow the steps below.

  1. Open a spreadsheet in your preferred spreadsheet program, such as Microsoft Excel.
  2. In the spreadsheet, use the header line below.  
    primary_id,sub_id,name,description
  3. In a separate window, open the regulation or framework that your template is based on. 
  4. In the regulation or framework, identify an actionable requirement in the regulation or framework. To learn how to differentiate between requirements that are actionable and requirements that are not actionable, see the Identifying Actionable Requirements section above.
  5. By using the table below, enter the requirement's information into the spreadsheet.
    Header Description  Character Limit
    primary_id Enter a Primary ID for the requirement. To learn about the Primary ID, see the Using the Primary ID and Sub ID Fields section below.  1-20 characters
    sub_id Enter a Sub ID for the requirement. To learn about the Sub ID, see the Using the Primary ID and Sub ID Fields section below.  1-20 characters
    name Enter a name that you can use to identify the requirement.   1-255 characters
    description Enter a requirement description. This description can include objectives, processes, or procedures that your organization must implement and document to meet the requirement.  1-65,535 characters 
    Important:We recommend that you avoid including the < and > special characters in your spreadsheet. When you import the CSV file into your platform, these special characters can cause fields to import unsuccessfully.
  6. Repeat step 4 and step 5 until you have entered all actionable requirements into the spreadsheet.  
    Note:When you import a CSV file into your platform, KCM GRC automatically removes duplicate entries. For example, if you enter two requirements with the same Primary ID, Sub ID, name, and description, only one of the requirements will import.
  7. Save the spreadsheet as a CSV file. 
    Important: If you are using Microsoft Excel for your spreadsheet, you must save your CSV file in the CSV UTF-8 (Comma-delimited) format.

Using the Primary ID and Sub ID Fields

In the Primary ID and Sub ID fields, you can enter the Primary ID and Sub ID for each requirement. Then, when you add requirements to a template, the characters you entered into the Primary ID and Sub ID fields will combine to create the requirement's Requirement ID. For example, if your Primary ID is "a" and your Sub ID is "1", the Requirement ID would be "a.1".

Requirements are ordered by their Requirement IDs in templates and in the scopes that are converted from templates. KCM GRC uses natural sort order to sort requirements by Requirement ID. By using this method, Requirement IDs are sorted in alphabetical and numerical order, and numbers with multiple digits are considered as one number. For example, a requirement with Requirement ID "a.3" would appear before a requirement with Requirement ID "a.20." You can select a separator, including as a comma, hyphen, period, or space, when you import or add requirements into your platform.

Note: You can use numbers, letters, and special characters in the Primary ID and Sub ID fields. When we create KCM GRC's managed templates, we use the Primary ID and Sub ID to reference the section and subsection that the requirement is located in, within the framework. 

Importing the Spreadsheet into KCM GRC

After you save your spreadsheet, follow the steps below to import your requirements into KCM GRC.

  1. From the Template Requirements section of the template page, click the Import button.
  2. From the Import Requirement CSV window, click the Click to Upload button.
  3. Select the CSV file that contains your requirements.
  4. (Optional) In the preview of requirements that will be imported, click the trash can icon to remove any requirements from the import.
  5. (Optional) Use the ID Separator menu to select a character that the system will place between the Primary ID and Sub ID for each of your requirements. This is a visual preference. If you do not make a selection, the default ID separator will be used, as described below.
    Note: If your Primary ID and Sub ID only contain numbers, the default separator will be a period (.). If your Primary ID and Sub ID contain numbers and letters, the default separator will be a space ( ).
  6. Click the Add Requirements button to import the requirements into your template.

Once you have added all of the necessary requirements to this template, you can convert it to a scope. See our How to Convert a Template to a Scope article for instructions.

Mapping Existing Requirements

You can map requirements that already exist in your account to your template. This includes requirements that you've added from the View All Requirements page, requirements that you've added to other custom templates, and requirements in managed templates.

Follow the steps below to map requirements to your template.

  1. From the Template Requirements area of the template page, click the Map button.
  2. In the Map Requirements to Template modal window, use the check boxes to select the requirements that you want to map. 
  3. Scroll to the bottom of the window and click Done Mapping.

Once you have added all of the necessary requirements to this template, you can convert it to a scope. See our How to Convert a Template to a Scope article for instructions.

Creating Requirements One-By-One

Follow the steps below to create template requirements individually. Please see the Identifying Actionable Requirements section for examples of requirements. 

  1. From the Template Requirements area of the page, click the Create button.
  2. Add details for your requirement by following the instructions below.
    1. Name: Add a name to identify your requirement.
    2. Description: Describe the purpose of the requirement. The requirement description can include objectives, processes, or procedures that need to be implemented and documented in order to meet the requirement.
    3. Primary ID and Sub ID: Enter a Primary ID and Sub ID for the requirement. To learn about the Primary ID and Sub ID, see the Using the Primary ID and Sub ID Fields section below. 
    4. ID Separator: (Optional) Use the drop-down menu to select a character that the system will place between the Primary ID and Sub ID for each of your requirements. This is a visual preference. If you do not select a character, the default ID separator will be used, as described below.
      Note:If your Primary ID and Sub ID only contain numbers, the default separator will be a period (.). If your Primary ID and Sub ID contain numbers and letters, the default separator will be a space ( ).
  3. Click the Create button.
  4. Repeat steps 1-3 for each requirement that you want to add to your template.

Once you have added all of the necessary requirements to this template, you can convert it to a scope. See our How to Convert a Template to a Scope article for instructions.

articles.name: How to Use the Custom Questions Tab of Your Platform
articles.title: How to Use the Custom Questions Tab of Your Platform
articles.body:
This article explains the Custom Questions area of your console. You can use the Custom Questions page to create, view, or edit the questions that you want to use in multiple questionnaires. Once you've created custom questions, you can add them to questionnaires from the questionnaire builder.

Note: As a best practice, we recommend creating custom questions prior to creating questionnaires. See our Vendor Risk Management Module Guide for the full suggested order of workflow when onboarding with your VRM module.

Follow the sections below to learn more about creating and working with custom questions.

Custom Questions Repository

You will find the Custom Questions area under the Vendor Risk Management module portion of your KCM GRC account. From the navigation panel, click Vendor Management > Custom Questions.

The Custom Questions page is a repository of all of the custom questions that have been created in your account. This includes the following:

  • Questions you have created in the questionnaire builder
  • Questions you have imported into the questionnaire builder
  • Questions you have created from the Custom Questions page

From the Custom Questions page, you can edit the custom questions that are not included in an active questionnaire. For more information about editing custom questions, see the Editing Custom Questions section below.

Creating Custom Questions

Follow the steps below to create custom questions from the Custom Questions page: 

  1. From the left-hand navigation panel, click Vendor Management > Custom Questions.
  2. Click the Create New Custom Question button on the top right-hand side of the page.
  3. In the Create Custom Question modal window, type your question in the text box. 
    Tip: You can format your questions on multiple lines. When typing, press the Return or Enter button on your keyboard and your formatting will be saved.
    1. Then, use the drop-down menu to the right to select a format for the question. Options include: Free Form Text, Multiple Choice, Checkbox, or Yes/ No/ N/A.
      Tip: Question configurations will slightly vary, depending on which question format you're using. See the Method 3: Creating and Configuring Custom Questions section of our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article for configuration details and for details about the user experience with each question format.
    2. For Multiple Choice and Checkbox questions: Configure the question by adding Answer Options.
    3. For Multiple Choice and Yes / No / N/A questions: Click the appropriate radio button under Correct to define the correct answer for the question.
  4. Click the Add button to add your question to your Custom Questions repository. If you'd like to create another question at this time, click the Add Another checkbox before clicking Add.

Once you've created a custom question, you will add it to a questionnaire from the questionnaire builder. For more information, see the Adding Custom Questions to Questionnaires section below. 

Editing Custom Questions

From the Custom Questions page, you can edit the custom questions that you have already added to your platform.

It is important to note that custom questions are dynamic. This means if you edit a custom question, from either the Custom Questions page or from a questionnaire, all instances of the question are affected. This is further-explained in the two examples, below: 

  • Custom Question A has been added to three questionnaires. From the Custom Questions page, you edit Custom Question A. The changes that you've made to Custom Question A are reflected in each of the three questionnaires.
  • Conversely, Custom Question A has been added to three questionnaires. You open one of these questionnaires and edit Custom Question A (from the questionnaire builder). The changes that you've made to Custom Question A are reflected in the other two questionnaires and on the Custom Questions page. 
Important: You cannot edit or delete custom questions that are in an active questionnaire. Questionnaires are considered active when they are in "Reviewed" status.

Follow the steps below to edit a custom question from the Custom Questions page:

  1. Click the pencil icon button to the right of the question (shown below).
  2. Make the necessary changes, then click the checkmark icon button to save your updates.

The changes are immediately applied to all instances of the custom question.

Adding Custom Questions to Questionnaires

After custom questions have been added to your account, add them to your questionnaires from the questionnaire builder. 

Follow the steps below to add custom questions to a questionnaire: 

  1. Create a new questionnaire or open a questionnaire that is not finalized, meaning, not in "Reviewed" status. See our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article for details about creating or finalizing a questionnaire.
  2. On the left side of the page, in the Add Questions From: area, select the first button on the left, as shown below.
  3. From the Questionnaire Templates modal window, click Custom Questions on the left-hand side.
  4. Use the checkboxes to the left of the questions to select the custom questions you want to add. To add all of your custom questions, click the top-level checkbox.
    Tip: In this modal window, custom questions are ordered by the most recent Last Updated date. Navigate to the Custom Questions page to see the Last Updated dates for custom questions.
  5. Click the Add button to add the selected questions to your questionnaire.
    Note:For details about the "CAIQ" and "SIG" selections that are available in this modal window, please see the Method 1: Adding Questions from System Templates section of our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article.
  6. Now, you will configure point values for each custom question. To view the questions you've added, click All. Then, click Custom Questions.
  7. Click the pencil icon button and add a value to the Points field. Repeat this step for each custom question that you have added to the questionnaire.
    Tip:Alternatively, you can assign the same point value to all of the questions in your questionnaire. For more information, see the Configuring System Template Questions section of our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article.

articles.name: Whitelist in Cisco Ironport
articles.title: Whitelist in Cisco Ironport
articles.body:
If you're using Cisco Ironport spam filtering, you can whitelist KnowBe4 to allow our simulated phishing test emails and training notifications through to your end users.

The instructions below include information from the Cisco whitelisting article. If you run into issues whitelisting KnowBe4 in Cisco Ironport, we recommend reaching out to Cisco for specific instructions. You can also contact our support team whenever you need assistance.

Whitelisting Cisco Ironport

To whitelist KnowBe4 in Cisco Ironport, do the following:

  1. From the Cisco Ironport admin console, navigate to the Mail Policies tab.
  2. Select HAT Overview. Please ensure that InboundMail lister is selected.
  3. Click WHITELIST. If you do not see WHITELIST, you can create your own group named "WHITELIST".
  4. Click Add Sender and add our IPs or hostnames. For the most up-to-date list of our IP addresses and hostnames, see our Whitelisting Data and Anti-Spam Information article.
  5. Click Submit and then Commit Changes.
Note:After following this article, we recommend setting up a test phishing campaign to 1-2 users to ensure your whitelisting was successful. As a last resource, we suggest reaching out to your service  provider for assistance. Visit here for an email template you can send to your service provider.

Skipping Outbreak Filter Scanning

The instructions above for whitelisting Cisco Ironport do not prevent Ironport's Outbreak Filter from scanning emails from our IPs or hostnames. If you are experiencing issues with our emails being quarantined, you may also need to set our IPs or hostnames to bypass this filter. 

To skip Outbreak Filter Scanning, do the following:

  1. From your Cisco Ironport admin console, navigate to the Mail Policies tab.
  2. Under the Message Modification section, enter our IP addresses or hostnames in the Bypass Domain Scanning table. For the most up-to-date list of our IP addresses and hostnames, see our Whitelisting Data and Anti-Spam Filtering Information article.
  3. Click Submit and then Commit Changes.

Troubleshooting

If Cisco Ironport is flagging KnowBe4's simulating phishing emails as spam or removing attachments from these emails, you may need to troubleshoot further in Cisco Ironport.

For a potential troubleshooting method, see the steps below. If you don't see the solution you're looking for, we recommend reaching out to Cisco Ironport for assistance.

  1. Create an individual HAT Mail Flow Policy specifically for KnowBe4.
  2. In this policy, disable Spam Detection and Virus Protection. For more information, see Cisco Ironport's Mail Flow Policy documentation.
  3. Add a sender group for our IP addresses or hostnames. For the most up-to-date list of our IP addresses and hostnames, see our Whitelisting Data and Anti-Spam Filtering Information article.
  4. Apply the policy to the sender group. For more information, see Cisco Ironport's Message Handing documentation.
Tip: To ensure that you have whitelisted correctly, see our How to Verify You Have Whitelisted KnowBe4 Correctly article.

articles.name: Partner and Multi-Account: Manage Partners
articles.title: Partner and Multi-Account: Manage Partners
articles.body:
From the Partners tab, you can view, edit, and delete your partners. From the Partner information page, you can also view and archive accounts managed by your partners. If you select the domain of an account managed by a partner account, you will be able to view and manage the account as an admin.

Tip:If you're looking for information about the accounts you manage, see our Partner/Multi-Account: Viewing Your Accounts article.

Managing Partners

To view your managed partners, navigate to the Partners tab of your Account Management console. For more information about this tab, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. + Create Partner: Click this button to add a new partner.
  2. Organization: This column displays the name of the organization. You can click the name of the organization in this column to access the partner’s information.
  3. Domain: This column displays the partner’s domain.
  4. Download CSV: Click this button to download a CSV file that contains information about your partners. 
  5. Impersonate Partner: Click this icon to impersonate the partner’s account management console as a child partner admin. This option is only available for your management console admins with Full Access Admin permissions.
  6. Actions: Click this drop-down menu and select Edit to make changes to a partner account.

Creating a New Partner

To create a new partner account, follow the steps below:

  1. From the Partners tab, click the + New Partner button. When you click this button, the New Partner pop-up window will open.
  2. Fill out the fields in the Personal Information and Organization Information sections with information about the partner.
  3. Fill out the fields in the Account Management Admin Settings section with your preferred settings for the partner account. From the Account Session Timeout drop-down menu, you can select the session timeout window to apply to the account. This setting will determine the maximum amount of idle time allowed before an admin will be logged out of the account.
  4. If you would like to enable SAML for the partner account, fill out the fields in the SAML section.
  5. Fill out the fields in the Purchased Products and Add-ons section. In the Number of Purchased Seats field, make sure to enter the number of seats the partner account purchased. Also, make sure the Subscription End Date fields both accurately reflect the partner account's KnowBe4 subscription period.
  6. Click Create Partner.

Editing an Existing Partner

To edit an existing partner account, follow the steps below:

  1. From the Partners tab, click the Edit button next to the partner account you would like to edit.
  2. Update any fields that need to be updated.
  3. Click Update Partner to save your edits.

Managing KnowBe4 Accounts Under Managed Partners

On the Partner Information page, you can view information about the partner accounts and any accounts they manage. For more information, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Accounts: This subtab displays a list of accounts that the partner manages.
  2. Status: Click this drop-down menu to filter the Accounts list by account status. You can select Active to view a list of all active accounts, Archived to view all archived accounts, or All to view a list of archived and active accounts.
  3. Billing Type: Click this drop-down menu to filter the Accounts list by billing type. You can select Paid, Trial, or Free. You can also select Any to view a list of all accounts managed by the partner.
  4. Search by domain or name: Use this field to search for specific accounts.
  5. Organization: Select the name of the organization's Account Information page. From the organization’s Account Information page, you can edit the account and view the account as an admin. For more information about managing accounts, see our Partner/Multi-Account: Viewing Your Accounts article.
  6. Actions: Click this drop-down menu to refresh the account’s Phish-prone Percentages.
  7. View as Partner Admin: Click this icon to impersonate the partner’s account management console as a child partner admin. This option is only available for your management console admins with Full Access Admin permissions.

articles.name: Security Culture Survey (SCS) Overview
articles.title: Security Culture Survey (SCS) Overview
articles.body:
You can assign a Security Culture Survey (SCS) organizational assessment to your users to assess your organization's security culture. Security culture is defined as the ideas, customs, and social behaviors that impact your organization’s security.

Your survey results will provide you with an overview of the seven dimensions that make up your security culture and an overall security culture score for your organization. You can use this information to establish a baseline for your security culture, to determine the changes you need to make to your security protocols, and to measure how your security culture evolves over time.

To develop the questions in this survey, we used a scientific research approach. For more information about how these questions were created and why we use the seven dimensions, see our KnowBe4 Security Culture Survey technical document.

In this article, you'll learn how to use the SCS and how to review your organization’s survey results. For more information about how to use organizational assessments effectively, see our How to Use Organizational Assessments article.

Best Practices

We recommend that you assign the Security Culture Survey to your users after their first 90 days of employment. We recommend that you wait at least 90 days to ensure that your users have adjusted to your organization's security culture. After the first survey, you should continue to assess your users once per year. If you assess your users once per year, you will be able to see how your organization's security culture changes over time.

Assigning Organizational Assessments

To assign an organizational assessment, add the assessment through the ModStore by searching for assessments and clicking the + Add to Library button. Then, you can create a training campaign with the assessment as the selected content by following the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 console and navigate to Training > Campaigns.
  2. Click + Create Training Campaign.
  3. From the Content drop-down menu, select the assessment you'd like to assign.

  4. Fill out all required fields for the campaign. For more information on how to create a new campaign, see our Creating and Managing Training Campaigns article.
  5. Click Create Campaign.

Completing the Security Culture Survey in the Learner Experience

To complete the Security Culture Survey, your users will log in to their Learner Experience (LX) and click the Training tab. Then, they'll locate the Security Culture Survey and click Start.

After they click Start, your users have the option to either start the survey or complete the survey later. If the user clicks Take Survey Now, they must answer all 32 questions to complete the survey. If the user does not have time to take the survey immediately, we recommend they click Come Back Later when they have time to take the full survey.

After your users complete the survey, they will be directed to a thank-you page.

On this thank you page, your users will also have the opportunity to submit anonymous feedback. This feedback can be downloaded from the Assessment Results tab of the campaign. For more information about downloading user feedback, see the Survey Culture Survey Results section below.

Monitoring Your Security Culture Survey Campaign

After you assign the Security Culture Survey to your users, you can view your users' progress. To view your users' progress, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account and navigate to Training > Campaigns.
  2. On the Campaigns subtab, click the name of the campaign in which the survey was assigned.
  3. On the Campaign Overview page, find the survey and click User Progress under the survey title.

From the Users page, you can see information about your users' progress, including when they were enrolled in the survey campaign, if they've started the survey, and how much time they've spent on the survey. See below for more information about the Users page:

  1. Download CSV: Click this button to download a CSV file of the information displayed in the table below.
  2. Actions: Click this drop-down menu to select the action you'd like to perform on the selected user or users. Options include:
    • Send Notification: Send a manual notification to the user about their survey.
    • Mark as Completed: Manually mark the user's survey as complete.
    • Reset Progress: Allow the user to restart the survey.
  3. Enrollment Date: Displays the date when the user was enrolled in the survey campaign.
  4. Content Started: Displays a check mark if the user started their survey.
  5. Time Spent: Shows how much time the user spent taking the survey.
  6. Time Remaining: Shows how much time the user has remaining to take the survey before the due date.

For more information about managing your users' progress, see our User Training Progress article.

Security Culture Survey Results

After your users take their Security Culture Survey, you will be able to see the survey results. To view your organization's survey results, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account and navigate to Training > Campaigns.
  2. On the Campaigns subtab, click the name of the campaign in which the survey was assigned.
  3. On the Campaign Overview page, find the survey and click Assessment Results under the survey’s title.

On the Assessment Results page, you can view your Security Culture Score. This score is the average score for your organization’s Security Culture Survey results. Under this score, you can also view the Security Culture Index. This index shows you if your organization’s security culture score is considered Excellent, Good, Moderate, Mediocre, or Poor.

Note: Your Security Culture Score includes users who are enrolled in the Security Culture Survey, but have not completed the survey. These incomplete surveys will lower your organization’s Security Culture Score. For best results, encourage your users to complete the survey as soon as they can.

On the Assessment Results page, you can also view the Results by Dimension graph. This graph shows your organization’s Security Culture Survey results by dimension. The seven dimensions are listed below:

  • Cognition
  • Behavior
  • Responsibility
  • Compliance
  • Attitudes
  • Communication
  • Norms

In the Security Culture Dimensions section at the bottom of the page, you can learn more about each dimension. These dimensions are presented in the order of your organization’s highest-scoring to lowest-scoring dimension. To learn more about a specific dimension, click the plus (+) button next to the dimension name. For more information about these dimensions and what you can do to change your score for each dimension, see our The seven dimensions of security culture document. For more information about the Security Culture Index, see our The Security Culture Index document.

Tip: In the dimension description, you can also learn tips for improving your security culture score for that dimension. To find the tip, look for the lightbulb icon in the dimension description.

Beneath the Results by Dimensions radar graph, you have the option to click the Download User Feedback button. You can click this button to export a CSV file of any feedback your users provided at the end of their survey.

Tip: On your Dashboard, review the Security Culture Survey widget to compare your organization's SCS score to others in your industry. See our Industry Benchmarking article for more information.

2025 SCS Update

While the Security Culture Survey was originally released in 2020, we released a revised version in 2025 that includes improvements to the questions for the specific dimensions.

Based on feedback and research, KnowBe4 has updated all included questions and answers for clarity and relevance. Specifically, the survey responses were updated to be more semantically appropriate, timely, and improved for content validity.

For this version of the Security Culture Survey, we ensured that each assessment a user receives includes three to six questions per individual dimension, each covering a different aspect of a particular dimension. We evaluated the quality of our items following a rigorous scientific method, using customer data from various industries and cultures worldwide.

For more information about the Security Culture Survey update, please see our Security Culture Survey (SCS) Version 2 technical document.

articles.name: How Can I Engage My Third Parties in My Vendor Risk Management Module?
articles.title: How Can I Engage My Third Parties in My Vendor Risk Management Module?
articles.body:
In order to ensure that your organization gets the most value out of the Vendor Risk Management module, it is crucial to have involvement from your third-party, or vendor contacts. We recommend sending an email out to all vendor contacts explaining the importance of their participation in completing questionnaire requests and following up with potential issues.    

We've offered a template below that you can use as a starting point for your email to your vendor contacts. Be sure to review the following text prior to sending to ensure the content matches your unique initiatives and change any text in brackets to personalize the template.

   Hello [Vendor Contact Name],

Having a compliance plan in place ensures that our organization runs smoothly and helps us stay focused on our organizational goals. One of our compliance initiatives includes completing a due diligence process with our vendors. This process allows us to confirm the safeguards our vendors have in place within their organization and assists us in maintaining our overall compliance goals. 

First, we will create an account for you within our Vendor Risk Management portal. At this time, you will receive an email invitation to confirm your account. From there, you will receive an additional email notification with a request to complete our questionnaire. After the questionnaire has been submitted for our review, it's possible that we may follow up on your responses by requesting clarification and/or supporting documentation. We refer to these requests as "Issues". It's important that you review these issues and respond in a timely manner to finalize your questionnaire. 

The portal is easy to navigate, but if you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to reach out to [Company Contact Information]. Also, see our How to Complete Questionnaires and Respond to Issues: A Guide for Vendor Users article for helpful tips and instructions. 

We look forward to [beginning or continuing] our partnership with your organization and appreciate your cooperation with this process.

Thank you,

[Your Name]
